Award.AwardTitle: Managing Downstream Patient Flow Processes Using Improved Coordination and Staffing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop models and study the downstream patient flow processes from the perspective of in-hospital staffing decisions for the escort staff. Queuing models will be developed using real life operational data. These models will be used to estimate the properties of the waiting time incurred by a patient, while waiting for transfer to an in-hospital unit from the emergency department. The waiting time properties will be used in an optimization model that will determine the staffing level. The optimization model will incorporate quality of service constraints. Solution techniques for solving this optimization model will be developed.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improvements in modeling and solution techniques for making shift staffing decisions in the emergency department patient transfer process. The primary goal of this work is to determine the right number of escort staff at the emergency department during a shift. Determining the right number of escort staff will reduce patient admission delays resulting from the unavailability of an escort staff, when required for patient transport. Reducing patient admission delays will free up capacity in the emergency department, which will improve patient safety in emergency departments that run at near capacity. This work will also help reduce the overall patient care cost due to more effective utilization of resources, and contribute to developing new modeling methods and computational tools available for staffing problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project conducted research on a major public health problem of Emergency Department overcrowding. Scientifically rigorous approaches were studied towards transport staff resource allocation that help reduce ambulance diversions and reduce Emergency Department waiting time by reducing the number of blocked beds due to delay in patient transport. Specifically, models based approaches were developed to improve downstream patient flow to reduce the ED boarding time in the Emergency department through improved management of the patient transportation system. We studied a combination of optimization over simulated systems for this purpose and staffing models were developed after analyzing real-word data, which was collected from Northwestern Memorial Hospital.

 

Methodologies to develop efficient algorithms for determining the optimal transportation staffing during each hour and a minimal number of servers that achieves certain waiting time requirements were studied. In adequacy to solve the problems using existing commercial simulation software was identified. Models that approximates the performance of the M-design queue by decomposing the system into multiple A-design queues.  A special case of two customer types being served by a single general server and a Bernoulli random variable is used to decide the next unit to serve. Laplace-Stieltjes Transforms (LSTs) of the waiting time distributions for each customer type was studied further. Methodologies for approximating the bounds on quality of service requirements were developed, and a branch-and-bound algorithm for optimizing resource allocation in an M-design queue by using novel ways (using conditions on queue stability, methods for generating lower and upper bounds on the possible allocation, etc.) that restrict the size of the feasible set using deterministic linear integer programming, and queue decomposition.  Since no known technique provides an exact estimation of the waiting time for the quality of service, we also developed simulations to study the properties of the approximations under different service time distributional settings and different levels of congestion in the system.  These simulations were implemented using the Python programming language.

 

Industrial Engineering undergraduate and PhD students were trained on the project. A design team of five Industrial Engineering undergraduate students worked on the project at an early stage.  A female graduate student worked on the research project during this year. In addition, a second female undergraduate student worked on the project during the summer as a REU. The PhD student is expected to complete her dissertation on the topic of this proposed research later this year. The research results will be disseminated in the form of her PhD dissertation, technical reports and research papers resulting from the proposed work.
